Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Michael Love, of California State University, Northridge, along with colleagues and students from US and Guatemalan universities, will conduct an archaeological investigation of early urbanism at the site of La Blanca, Guatemala. Previous scholarship on Mesoamerican urbanism has placed its first appearance in the Classic Period (ca AD 300- AD 900), but recent evidence suggests that urbanism began much earlier, during the Middle Preclassic period (ca 1000-600 BC). Urbanization is a phenomenon that brings into focus many topics of broad interest to the social sciences and the humanities. As a process, urbanization changed the relationships between many social and cultural variables including demography, economy, political structures, and religious practices. Analysis of first-generation urbanization therefore offers an important opportunity to achieve a holistic perspective on important changes in the human condition as well as a myriad of social issues. As one of the limited number of cases in the world where urban centers developed independently, Mesoamerica plays a major role in the worldwide comparative analysis of first generation cities and urbanism. As one of Mesoamerica's first settlements of urban scale, La Blanca is a key site in understanding first-generation cities.

Love's research will examine how daily life was altered by urbanization and how people brought together in an early city negotiated their lives with one another. La Blanca was established when groups from a broad hinterland came together at a new location. This form of aggregation seems typical of early cities throughout the world. A primary question is whether these people of different backgrounds merged into a single new group, or whether they remained mostly independent of one another and maintained separate identities. Love's study will examine three different areas of the city and ask whether they were integrated with one another through a single hierarchical system, or whether the districts were autonomous and only loosely integrated with one another. Love and his colleagues will examine the material remains of a number of households in each district of La Blanca and analyze the evidence of daily life preserved in houses, food remains, tools, and ritual items. The team will collect data on household economic activity (such as subsistence practices, craft production), as well as domestic ritual activity, including rituals of ancestor veneration. Those data will then be used to determine whether economic and ritual activity were organized primarily within each district or integrated at the level of the city itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the world now lives in cities, but in the ancient world the development of the first cities radically altered the way people lived. Understanding how and why the first cities came about is important to understanding the history of the human experience and how the modern world came to be. Research at the ancient settlement of La Blanca, Guatemala examined how early cities were created in Mesoamerica in the Preclassic period (2000 BC- AD 300). A number of different scenarios were considered and then evaluated against archaeological evidence. Were cities created by slow growth of population, or by a conscious act of aggregation? Was the process driven by popular sentiment or through the actions of a few members of the elite?  Data were collected through intensive survey, collection of surface materials, and excavation of domestic areas of the site. These fresh data were integrated with previously collected data from household excavations and monumental (public) sectors of the site.  Previous work at the site had identified four residential sectors at La Blanca and research focused on evaluating the relationships between them. Were these sectors autonomous in a way that suggests they represented independent social groups, or were they integrated in a way that suggests a highly centralized political and economic hierarchy? The project looked at the chronology of settlement within each sector, the economic activities within it, evidence for public ritual structures in each zone, and evidence of household ritual activity.  Both surface collections and pottery analysis of domestic zones show an uneven history of occupation in the site. There is no sign of major occupation at the site during the Early Preclassic (2000-900 BC), and the site is founded at about 900 BC and the monumental construction at the site also takes place soon after that date. The central and southeastern zones of the site were occupied early in the site’s history, but occupation in the northern and southwestern zone occurred relatively late. Hence, the idea that the city was founded as a result of rapid aggregation, but the idea that settlement came about as an alliance between more or less equal social groups was rejected. Ceremonial architecture in the northern and southwestern groups are probably not reflections of neighborhood independence in ritual matters.  Precise mapping showed that the ceremonial mound in the northern group was functionally part of the city’s central ceremonial architectural plan and linked to a water source that flows to the central zone.  A large mound in the southwestern group was proven to be Late Classic  (AD 600-900) in date, although it was constructed over a Middle Preclassic (900-600 BC) residential mound. The data on household economic and ritual activity are still under detailed analysis by specialists, but preliminary data do not show indications that the residential zones were the basis for economic activity.  Indeed, the residential clusters don’t appear to reflect any kind of social or cultural identity, but instead look to be a product of resource availability. Residences were built around naturally occurring depressions (probably the remnants of ancient water courses). Instead of four large residential clusters, more refined data appear to show 8-10 residential clusters, built on high ground around these water sources. While the model of four quasi-autonomous districts can be discounted at La Blanca, a highly centralized model is not strongly supported.  Using jade density as a scale for ranking household socio-economic status, elite residences were identified in both the central and the southeastern zones of the site.  There are more elite residences in the central zone than elsewhere, but they are not found exclusively in that area.  In sum, La Blanca tends to a model of centralized political and economic power, but not strongly so.  Ritual activity can now be seen as highly centralized and focused on the monumental core. Ongoing analysis of materials from  domestic zones will be needed to reach a final conclusion on the degree of centralization of economic activity. Nonetheless, the evidence strongly indicates that this early city in Mesoamerica was founded through the rapid aggregation of population, rather than being created through the gradual growth of a smaller settlement.
